poem:
**Calm Autumnal Days**

In a quiet armistice with the sea,  
the Channel cradles its own reflection,  
an invitation written in tranquil tide.  
The boats whisper across the water,  
stories folded tight against their hulls,  
each arrival a footnote to weather's hand—  
the sky's open palm,  
the ocean's gentle beckon.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Weather blamed for small boat arrivals under Labour passing 20,000 The number of small boat arrivals since Keir Starmer took power has passed 20,000, with the Home Office claiming a record number of calm autumnal days in the Channel was responsible. A 31-day period in October and November had the highest ratio of so-called “red days” – when weather conditions make crossings likely or very likely – since records began in 2018, according to a". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
